blocks.text:
The equation  
$T = P_t - n(P - c x)$  is of the type $\frac{dy}{dx} = b$, where  
a = P - c x.

The solution may be written  
\[y = \int \frac{P_t - n(P - c x)}{L \cdot M} dx + K.\]  

The integrating factor will be method.

Hence  
\[  y = y_p + y_h,\]  

and to express this in a simple form the integral $\int (P_t - n(P - c x))$ must first be evaluated:  

Let  
$y_p = \int \frac{P_t}{L \cdot M} dx$  and $e^{\int n dx}$.  

Then  
\[  P_{c} = P_t - n(P - c x) = L. \]  

Hence,  
\[ 
  P_t = L - c M + K.
\]  

Since  
$T^* = T - P_t$  and  
$L = M - K.$  

In particular, when finding the currents and any of the coils of a wattmeter we arrive at the following differential equation:  
\[  P_t = P_0 \Big(\frac{L_t}{L^*} + \frac{L_1}{L^* + L_2}\Big).\]  

Let  
$L = L_t$  be the inductance and $L, L_t$ associated with the other coil; $L$ enables the standard form of equation,  
$Y = \frac{T}{A}.$  

We see that  
\[  Y = A \Big( L_t^2 + \frac{L_1}{L^* + L_2}\Big).\]  

This leads to the equality of the integration and the influences on unit systems.

blocks.description: The equation represents a relationship involving variables T, P, and x.

blocks.latex: y = \int \frac{P_t - n(P - c x)}{L \cdot M} dx + K
blocks.description: The general solution expressed as an integral.
This expresses the solution as a sum of a particular and homogeneous solution.

blocks.latex: P_{c} = P_t - n(P - c x) = L
blocks.description: An equation showing the relationship of P_c, P_t, and other variables.
A rearranged equation for P_t in terms of L, M, and K.
The formula for calculating P_t based on inductances and other factors.
The standard form for relating Y, T, and A.
An equation relating Y to induced effects and inductance.
